title: Explore data in the Global Coal Plant Tracker
footer: All data comes from GEM's [Global Coal Plant Tracker](https://globalenergymonitor.org/projects/global-coal-plant-tracker/), last updated in July 2024. Units on this page are in gigawatts (GW). Under development includes all capacity with status announced, pre-permit, permitted, and construction.

dropdown.overall_summary: Global operating coal power capacity has increased 11% since 2015.
Operating coal power capacity in BRICS countries has increased 23% since 2015.

Operating coal power capacity in the 27 member states of the European Union (EU27) has fallen 34% since 2015.
Only a single coal-fired power station, in Poland, remains in development.

The Group of Seven major industrial countries (G7) accounts for 14% of the world’s operating coal capacity, down from 23% in 2015.
The G7 no longer has any coal in construction, but is still home to one proposal in Japan and two in the United States.
The Group of Twenty (G20) is home to 93% of the world’s operating coal capacity and 89% of coal capacity under consideration (in pre-construction stages).

Operating coal power capacity in countries part of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has fallen 26% since 2015.
Only four countries in the OECD, Australia, Japan, Türkiye, and the United States, are still considering coal projects.
Albania has no operating coal plants. It also has no coal power under development.
